results.title: ‘Licorice Pizza’ Review: California Dreaming and Scheming
results.abstract: In his latest movie, Paul Thomas Anderson returns to the San Fernando Valley for a shaggy 1970s romp about a self-important teenage boy and a memorable woman.

multimedia.caption: Cooper Hoffman and Alana Haim in “Licorice Pizza.” Hoffman, the son of Philip Seymour Hoffman, plays the film’s improbable teenage hero.
multimedia.copyright: Melinda Sue Gordon/Metro Goldwyn Mayer Pictures

results.title: ‘House of Gucci’ Review: Murder, Italian-Style
results.abstract: Lady Gaga, Adam Driver, Al Pacino and Jared Leto serve up a heaping platter of prosciutto in Ridley Scott’s tale of family treachery.

multimedia.caption: Lady Gaga and Adam Driver in “House of Gucci.”

results.title: ‘Drive My Car’ Review: A Director Takes Your Heart for a Spin
results.abstract: In this quiet masterpiece, Ryusuke Hamaguchi considers grief, love, work and the soul-sustaining, life-shaping power of art.

multimedia.caption: From left, Hidetoshi Nishijima and Toko Miura in “Drive My Car,” directed by Ryusuke Hamaguchi.

results.title: Here Are 5 Family-Friendly Things to Stream This Weekend
results.abstract: Hosting relatives for the holiday weekend? Here are some great films and series that will appeal to all ages.

multimedia.caption: From left, Asa Butterfield and Ben Kingsley in "Hugo."

results.title: With ‘Encanto,’ Stephanie Beatriz Finds Yet Another Voice
results.abstract: The actress, also featured in “In the Heights” and on the series “Brooklyn Nine-Nine,” discusses her lead role as Mirabel in the latest Disney animated film.

multimedia.caption: The actress Stephanie Beatriz in London. In 2021 she said farewell to “Brooklyn Nine-Nine” and started a slate of new projects.
multimedia.copyright: Kalpesh Lathigra for The New York Times

results.title: ‘Encanto’ Review: In This House, We Make Magic
results.abstract: Disney’s new film, about a gifted family in Colombia, has stunning animation, a beautifully composed story and spellbinding songs by Lin-Manuel Miranda.

multimedia.caption: Mirabel, center, voiced by Stephanie Beatriz, is the non-magical member of the Madrigal family in “Encanto,” the new animated Disney film.

results.title: ‘The Humans’ Review: Reasons (Not) to Be Cheerful
results.abstract: Stephen Karam’s film adaptation of his powerful play acquires a supernatural sheen as a family gathers for Thanksgiving dinner.

multimedia.caption: Clockwise from left: June Squibb, Amy Schumer, Steven Yeun, Beanie Feldstein, Richard Jenkins and Jayne Houdyshell in “The Humans.”

results.title: Haruki Murakami and the Challenge of Adapting His Tales for Film
results.abstract: “Drive My Car,” from the rising director Ryusuke Hamaguchi, is the rare movie based on the author’s work to excel. The writer and director explain the difficulties.

multimedia.caption: Hidetoshi Nishijima, left, and Toko Miura in “Drive My Car,” adapted from Haruki Murakami’s work.

results.title: ‘Resident Evil: Welcome to Raccoon City’ Review: They Go Way Back
results.abstract: Set in 1998, this franchise origin story embraces nostalgia.
des_facet: Resident Evil: Welcome to Raccoon City (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Robbie Amell and Kaya Scodelario in “Resident Evil: Welcome to Raccoon City.”

results.title: Matthew McConaughey Is Not Afraid to Go Down the Rabbit Hole
results.abstract: “Am I dipping into the spiritual realm and the infinite game of life? Damn right I am.”

results.title: ‘Encanto’ Reaches No. 1, but Moviegoers Are Tough to Lure Back
results.abstract: No simultaneous streaming: “Encanto” or “House of Gucci” could only be seen in theaters this weekend. Even still, some viewers stayed home.

multimedia.caption: The new Disney animated film “Encanto” took in $40.3 million in North America, much less than “Moana” did in 2016.

results.title: When Is a Horror Movie Not a Horror Movie?
results.abstract: When “The Humans” and other new dramas use jump scares and other genre staples, it’s a fair question to ask.

multimedia.caption: Amy Schumer in “The Humans,” a family drama that borrows horror elements.

results.title: Wakefield Poole, Pioneer in Gay Pornography, Dies at 85
results.abstract: He gave up a dance career to create a crossover, and now classic, hit film in 1971 that had both gay and straight audiences, and celebrities, lining up to see it.

multimedia.caption: Wakefield Poole in 1974, three years after the release of “Boys in the Sand,” a landmark film in gay erotica.

results.title: Stream These 7 Productions That Celebrate Stephen Sondheim’s Work
results.abstract: Here’s a guide to films, documentaries and other productions that provide insight into the composer-lyricist’s sly wit and melodic acumen.

multimedia.caption: Hal Prince, director of the original Broadway production of “Company,” and Elaine Stritch, one of the show’s stars, in D.A. Pennebaker's film “Original Cast Album: Company.”
multimedia.copyright: Museum of the Moving Image, via Photofest

results.title: Days Before Dying, Stephen Sondheim Reflected: ‘I’ve Been Lucky’
results.abstract: In an interview on Sunday, the revered composer and lyricist, 91, contentedly discussed his shows running on Broadway and off, as well as a new movie about to be released.

multimedia.caption: In a 90-minute interview on Sunday, Stephen Sondheim was engaged and playfully pugnacious, and gave little indication of being in ill health.
multimedia.copyright: Daniel Dorsa for The New York Times

results.title: On Their Small Shoulders Rest Some Big Films
results.abstract: Five children winning acclaim for their roles in “Belfast,” “King Richard,” “C’mon C’mon” and “The Tender Bar” talk us through their starring turns.

multimedia.caption: Woody Norman with the radio equipment his character’s uncle uses in “C’mon C’mon.”

results.title: Five Science-Fiction Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks include an amnesiac romance and acts of sentient killer robot rampage.

multimedia.caption: Olivia Cooke and Jack O’Connell in “Little Fish.”

results.title: A Refugee’s Harrowing Story, Finally Told Through Animation
results.abstract: Jonas Poher Rasmussen’s childhood friend kept his flight from Afghanistan secret for 20 years. Now, Rasmussen has told his story through the award-winning film “Flee.”

multimedia.caption: Jonas Poher Rasmussen, the director of “Flee,” was drawn to the creative possibilities that animation offers.
multimedia.copyright: Clement Pascal for The New York Times

results.title: ‘Writing With Fire’ Review: Speaking Truth to Power
results.abstract: This rousing documentary follows the reporters of India’s only all-women news outlet as they pivot to digital journalism while battling personal and political challenges.

multimedia.caption: Suneeta, a reporter in the documentary “Writing With Fire.”

results.title: ‘Burning’ Review: Pulling the Fire Alarm in Australia
results.abstract: A new documentary looks at the visceral impact of wildfires and climate change on the country, from its beleaguered people to sickly koalas.

multimedia.caption: From Eva Orner’s documentary “Burning.” Over 50 million acres went up in flames in Australia during its summer, 2019-2020, dwarfing losses in California or the Amazon.

results.title: ‘’Twas the Fight Before Christmas’ Review: A Not-So-Silent Night
results.abstract: This documentary recounts how an Idaho man filed a discrimination lawsuit after his neighbors refused to let him host an annual Christmas light extravaganza.

multimedia.caption: A scene from the documentary “’Twas the Fight Before Christmas.”

results.title: ‘A Castle for Christmas’ Review: Deck the Halls With Expensive Tartans
results.abstract: Charming locals in Scotland can’t save Brooke Shields and Cary Elwes from the script of this formulaic holiday rom-com.

multimedia.caption: In “A Castle for Christmas,” the best-selling author Sophie Brown (Brooke Shields) meets Myles (Cary Elwes), a duke with a castle in Scotland.

results.title: ‘A Boy Called Christmas’ Review: Kindling the Holiday Spirit
results.abstract: Enchanting imagery elevates this Netflix holiday adventure about a boy who journeys to a magic elfin city.

multimedia.caption: Henry Lawfull in “A Boy Called Christmas.”

results.title: ‘8-Bit Christmas’ Review: Now You’re Playing With Power
results.abstract: Nintendo looms large in this sentimental, 1980s-set holiday comedy.

multimedia.caption: Winslow Fegley and Steve Zahn in “8-Bit Christmas.”

results.title: They Adapted ‘Mrs. Doubtfire,’ and Their Personal Beliefs
results.abstract: Wayne and Karey Kirkpatrick have come a long way from their beginnings in Christian rock, but they’re glad to be creating a family-friendly musical comedy.

multimedia.caption: Wayne Kirkpatrick, left, and Karey Kirkpatrick at the Stephen Sondheim Theater, where their new musical, “Mrs. Doubtfire,” is in previews.
multimedia.copyright: Caroline Tompkins for The New York Times

results.title: ‘Keep Sweet’ Review: A Legacy of Polygamy in a Religious Sect
results.abstract: This documentary by Don Argott looks to the past and future of a community in the American West that made its own rules and lived by them.
des_facet: Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints

multimedia.caption: Loretta Barlow and her family in the documentary “Keep Sweet.”

results.title: ‘Moulin Rouge!’ Has a New Satine. She’s Amazed She’s Back on Broadway.
results.abstract: “I didn’t think I’d ever perform on Broadway again,” Natalie Mendoza said.

multimedia.caption: Natalie Mendoza in Central Park recently. “I knew this character, because I was there right at the beginning,” she said, referring to her work on the “Moulin Rouge” film.
multimedia.copyright: Mark Elzey for The New York Times

results.title: The Best Thanksgiving Movies to Stream
results.abstract: First the food, then the movies. Here are five streaming suggestions for the holiday.

multimedia.caption: Claire Danes, left, and Holly Hunter in “Home for the Holidays.”

results.title: Hayao Miyazaki Prepares to Cast One Last Spell
results.abstract: No artist has explored the contradictions of humanity as sympathetically and critically as the Japanese animation legend. Now, at 80, he’s coming out of retirement with another movie.

multimedia.caption: Hayao Miyazaki photographed outside his atelier near Studio Ghibli in Tokyo on Oct. 4, 2021.

results.title: ‘West Side Story’ Star Ariana DeBose Is Always Ready for Her Next Role
results.abstract: After dancing in ‘Hamilton’ and playing Anita in Steven Spielberg’s new musical adaptation, the actress has her sights on a part entirely her own.

multimedia.caption: Ariana DeBose photographed in New York City on October 18, 2021. Louis Vuitton dress, price on request, louisvuitton.com; and Panconesi earrings, $380, marcopanconesi.com.
multimedia.copyright: Photograph by Cheril Sanchez. Styled by Yohana Lebasi

results.title: ‘Touchy Feely,’ ‘Maggie’ and Other Streaming Gems
results.abstract: A look at off-the-radar recommendations for home viewing, including indie comedy-dramas, genre hybrids and informative documentaries about influential outsiders.

multimedia.caption: Rosemarie DeWitt plays a massage therapist in “Touchy Feely.”

results.title: Paul Thomas Anderson Goes Back to the Valley With ‘Licorice Pizza’
results.abstract: The auteur explains why he cast Alana Haim, and why he thinks the age difference in the film’s central relationship shouldn’t matter.

multimedia.caption: Paul Thomas Anderson, right, working with the camera operator Colin Anderson on the set of “Licorice Pizza.”

results.title: How Do You Make Teen Comedies Today? Buy a High School.
results.abstract: A former school outside Syracuse, N.Y., has been transformed into American High, a production hub for inexpensive films aimed at streaming platforms.

multimedia.caption: A former school is once again home to high school drama of the sort generally captured in R-rated teenage comedies.
multimedia.copyright: Libby March for The New York Times

results.title: Watch Dwayne Johnson Chase Ryan Reynolds in ‘Red Notice’
results.abstract: The director Rawson Marshall Thurber narrates a sequence set in a museum.

multimedia.caption: Ryan Reynolds and Dwayne Johnson in “Red Notice.”
